MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach when the Government expect to obtain vacant possession of the UCD premises (the School of Engineering) in Government Buildings, Merrion Street, Dublin; if such premises will be made available to the Houses of the Oireachtas; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: My Department are working closely with the Higher Education Authority and the university authorities on the gradual evacuation of the accommodation occupied by the School of Engineering in the Merrion Street premises and present indications are that vacant possession of about 2000m² will be secured between now and October next. The date when the balance of the accommodation will become available is not yet established.
The Office of Public Works are at present examining how the accommodation could best be used to alleviate the accommodation problems of the Oireachtas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach have in the information supplied to him the area of the balance of the accommodation which will become available after October?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I have that but perhaps it would be better to send it to the Deputy because it is a bit confused.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: At this stage is it appropriate that the Committee on Procedure and Privileges be consulted regarding the utilisation of the premises?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: It might be a bit premature but it should be done in plenty of time. We will ensure that the committee are consulted well in advance of any specific action.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Will the accommodation be made available to the Dáil? I was somewhat disturbed when Taoiseach to discover that there were plans to allocate part of it in such a way that the full accommodation would not be available to the Dáil as a result of a shift in the Taoiseach's office. I took the view that that should not happen and that all the space should be made available to the Dáil. Will the Taoiseach assure us that that is his intention?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: There are a number of alternatives being considered but the whole idea is that the Oireachtas should benefit from whatever arrangements are made.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The plans which I saw and which were put to me for approval—I did not approve them—involved allocation of space for the office of the Taoiseach at a point in the building which not only took up space but prevented space further down the corridor being available to the Dáil. The net effect was to increase the amount of the accommodation of the Department of the Taoiseach but not to give extra space to the Dáil. I am concerned about that.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I could assure the Deputy that there will be no attempt to improve the position of the Taoiseach at the expense of any other Members of the Oireachtas. Perhaps, as Deputy Quinn has suggested, these matters are best dealt with by the Committee on Procedure and Privileges.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Public Relations Contracts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will give details of any public relations contracts which he has placed since his appointment indicating in particular the names of the persons or firms involved, the length of the contracts and the contract sums or consultancy fees.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I have placed no such contracts since assuming office.
Question No. 3 postponed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Department of Culture and Arts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether he intends to implement the previous Government's decision to set up a Department of Culture and Arts with a view of co-ordinating responsibilities at present spread among many different Government Departments.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: No such decision was taken by the previous Government. The most effective way to co-ordinate all the cultural and artistic activities and responsibilities of the Government is under consideration at present. The Deputy will be aware that arrangements including the preparation of the necessary legislation for the setting up of a National Heritage Council are well advanced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: When does the Taoiseach expect this process of consideration to conclude? What stage of conclusion has the memorandum which is being circulated to the various Government Departments reached?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy referring to the National Heritage Council?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: I am referring to the subject matter of the question, a Department of Culture and Arts.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: There is no memorandum circulating to the Departments about that matter at present. No memorandum about the setting up of a Department of Culture and Arts has been circulated by the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The question relates to what the Taoiseach intends to do about the previous Government's decision. One had been circulated.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The question asks when we intend to implement the previous Government's decision and in my reply I pointed out that the previous Government did not take such a decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach aware of a policy commitment by the previous Government to set up such a Department? Will the Taoiseach indicate to the House his intention with regard to such a Department?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Strangely enough the Government do not feel bound by policy decisions taken by the previous Government in a number of areas. I have indicated in my reply that we are examining for ourselves — I hope the Deputy will grant us the privilege of doing that — how best the different cultural and artistic activities and responsibilities of the Government can be co-ordinated.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Northern Ireland Football Team.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he intends to send a formal message of good wishes to the Northern Ireland football team and officials for their success in the World Cup in Spain; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I do, of course, wish every success to the Irish Football Association and to the Northern Ireland team in the forthcoming World Cup finals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach be sending an invitation to them to visit him or will he be going to Belfast to wish them well?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I would dearly like to go to Belfast to wish them well if a suitable opportunity presented itself. I did not turn my mind to the question of inviting them to come to see me but now that the Deputy has raised it I will consider it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: If the Republic of Ireland team were going to Spain — we all wish they were — the Taoiseach would have been making efforts to try to contact them to wish them well, he would be paying a visit to the team's headquarters.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Not necessarily.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I would imagine that that type of thinking would be invading the Taoiseach's mind. What effort is the Taoiseach making to let it be known to the Irish Football Association that he would be available to go to wish them well?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I have not done anything as yet about the matter. However, now that the Deputy has raised it, I shall consider what might be done. I readily acknowledge that I have been given very valuable advice as to how to play the game.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will specify the constitutional amendments he envisaged when he referred to them in his address at the White House, Washington on 17 March, 1982.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: In the course of my White House speech on March 17 last to which the Deputy's question refers, I was speaking about the obstacles which need to be overcome in seeking to bring the partition of our country to an end and in this context I stated that we would make whatever constitutional arrangements might be thought to be needed.

I have spoken previously on a number of occasions, as I did on April 16 last, at a function commemorating the Bi-Centenary of Grattan's Parliament, of a new constitution for the whole island under which we might see a legislative assembly which spoke for the whole nation.

As I said on that occasion, our aim should be a political structure for the whole island which would banish exclusion, discrimination, bias and even condescension from Ireland forever; a political structure in which all traditions would find their representation as of right.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Which question is the Taoiseach answering?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I am answering Question No. 6.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: Seeing the seeming willingness on the part of the Taoiseach now to engage in constitutional reform, would he not think it worthwhile to begin to implement some policies of constitutional reform at this stage, rather than wait for some unspecified events to happen?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: No. The Deputy should be well aware of my position in that regard, which I have stated on a number of occasions. It would be a futile exercise to start making changes in our Constitution in order to accommodate different traditions without having the participation of the representatives of those traditions in the process.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That reply by the Taoiseach is at variance with his willingness to discuss with me the question of constitutional review, as stated in the Dáil some weeks ago. I hope that the Taoiseach has not changed his mind on the question of constitutional review.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I understand the Taoiseach's position to be that he, as most of us, would like to have an input from the people of Northern Ireland into what way we should frame a new Constitution.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: That would be essential.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: It is essential. In what way does the Taoiseach hope to reach that objective?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: As the Deputy knows, I would like to see a major input into that situation from the London Government. I hope that this process can be pursued constructively through the Anglo-Irish process.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: A final supplementary question from Deputy Harte.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: My question arises from the Taoiseach answering a different question. I have asked the Taoiseach in what way he plans to or believes he can obtain an opinion from all the people of Northern Ireland. He has answered that he seeks an opinion from the London Government. In what way does the Taoiseach hope to obtain an opinion from the Northern people, as outlined in his political thinking, to which I subscribe?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I look forward, ideally, to a situation where we will be all sitting around a table discussing this very matter, discussing new political structures and possibly a new Constitution for the island as a whole.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: As the Taoiseach has a commitment to have a referendum in the future on certain constitutional issues, surely he must consider it worthwhile to include other items which are unacceptable to the Northern Ireland community which will need changing in Southern Ireland?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I have already dealt with that matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Finally, if success is as lacking in the next 50 years as it was in the last 50, must we wait 50 years for the objectives at which the Taoiseach aims?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: No. It means that we rededicate ourselves to working towards that objective and trying to bring about the sort of situation which I have envisaged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach mean that we have not tried to do that in the past? People have tried and have not been successful. If success is as lacking in the future as it was in the past, must we wait 50 or 100 years to have a Constitution in this part of Ireland to which the Taoiseach aspires and with which we all agree?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Deputy knows that in these matters the thing to do is to devise a constructive, forward-looking policy and work to try to make this succeed. If it does not succeed, then we shall have to consider alternatives.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Is it not just a question of saying what we would like to see in our Constitution?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: In view of the statements which the Taoiseach has just made, in the event that the President refers the private rents legislation again to the Supreme Court, would the Taoiseach consider the possibility of joining to the pro-life question a constitutional amendment in relation to clarifying the balance between the rights of private property and the common good?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: That is a separate matter. As I have already indicated, my electoral commitment is to bring this forward as a separate constitutional amendment and I intend to do that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Deputy Kelly, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Could I just clarify one point and than I shall desist? Does that statement mean that the Taoiseach is ruling out any other constitutional issue?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach is not ruling them out?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: I thought I heard the Taoiseach say that his object was to bring the parties to the Irish question around a table. Would he please identify for the House one single act which can be attributed to his Government during the time he has been Taoiseach which has been likely to make that day come any sooner? One single act.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I would have to take some considerable time to outline all that I have done in that context.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: I am asking for only one, just one act.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach not going to answer that question?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I said that I would have to take a very considerable length of time to enumerate all the things I have done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: Just one.

Speaker.hpid: Deputies Deputies
Speaker.P: One.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: In fact, I have done far more practical and important things than the previous Government did.

Speaker.hpid: Deputies Deputies
Speaker.P: One.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: I am asking for just one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: In the national interests, would the Taoiseach reply?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Most of Deputy Kelly's contribution to this situation has been totally divisive.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: Just one.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: He cannot give one. He knows that he cannot.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: Just one?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Snookered?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I could enumerate a considerable number of things which I have done and, if the Deputy will put down a question, I will give him the answer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: We have a large number of questions to deal with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: What are the Taoiseach's intentions with regard to the committee set up by the previous Attorney General whose charge it was to look at, among other things, the Constitution with a view to bringing the day of which the Taoiseach speaks closer? Does he intend to continue the existence of that committee?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I do not know of the existence of any such committee or the setting up of any such committee by the previous Government. As far as I am aware, a committee with that particular objective was not set up by the previous Government.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: But the Taoiseach has already answered questions about this committee to which I have referred.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The committee to which Deputy Kelly refers was not set up by the previous Government.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. FitzGerald Dr. FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The committee was set up to bring forward meaningful changes in the Constitution, among which would be ones which would help to bring that day of which the Taoiseach speaks nearer.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: As far as I am aware, that was not one of the objectives of the committee.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: This should be by the way of a question.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: If the Deputy wishes to put down a question on the matter, I will answer it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach please answer Question No. 7?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Grattan's Parliament Bicentenary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if the Government intend to mark the bicentenary of Grattan's Parliament.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Yes. There are a number of events planned to commemorate the Bicentenary of Grattan's Parliament.

Some events have already taken place — a reception hosted by myself in the old Irish Parliament House, at the Bank of Ireland, College Green. This was held on 16 April 1982, which was the actual bicentenary date of Grattan's “Declaration of Independence” speech.

An article on Grattan's Parliament, by Professor J.C. Beckett was included in the April edition of the Department of Foreign Affairs' publication Ireland Today. At the moment also a school pack and film strip, which has been prepared by the Department of Education, is being distributed to schools throughout the country.

Other planned events are:—(i) a major exhibition covering the Grattan era to be held in the National Museum. This exhibition will commence towards the end of June; (ii) a commemorative plaque will be unveiled on the site of Grattan's former home on St. Stephen's Green; (iii) a bust in stone of Henry Grattan will be unveiled in Merrion Square Park later this year; (iv) a commemorative stamp to be issued in October.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Speaking recently at a bicentenary function in Parliament Buildings, the Taoiseach stated that Grattan's outlook on the future of Ireland was in line with and consistent with Fianna Fáil policy.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I did not say that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach care to comment on that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: He has commented.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: If he did not say this, did he correct that statement which appeared in the press that it was consistent with Fianna Fáil policy of today?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I will be very glad to let the Deputy have a copy of my speech, if he wishes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: Was the Taoiseach aware, when he made this statement referred to by Deputy Harte, that to the members of Grattan's Parliament the ideals and purposes of the United Irishmen and of Wolfe Tone were poison? How does he reconcile his attachment — or does it go any further than attending receptions or throwing them with public money — how does he reconcile the policy of Grattan's Parliament with the professed allegiance which his party has always shown to Wolfe Tone?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Deputy's question is based on some apparent statement which I did not make. I believe that Grattan's Parliament was a very important event in our history which made a great contribution, particularly to our economic development, and I do not feel it necessary to regard admiration for one particular position as necessarily being equivalent to condemning another.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I hope the Taoiseach will give me a straightforward answer to my question. The Taoiseach has been reported as saying that the developing policies of Grattan's Parliament were in line and consistent with Fianna Fáil policy. Would the Taoiseach clarify that statement?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Deputy is mistaken in what he is attributing to me and, as I said, I will do him the courtesy of sending him a copy of the speech which I made on that occasion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach proposing to commemorate a man and a Parliament for which he has no respect?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: This question asked me if the Government intend to mark the bicentenary of Grattan's Parliament and I have answered that question fully.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: Would it be fair to say that the Taoiseach's interest in Grattan's Parliament is what I might call a reception, a cheese-and-wine interest, considering the fact that the Department of Foreign Affairs bulletin of last week contained one picture of Grattan and three of the Taoiseach?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Touché.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: We have 558 questions for oral answer. Ceist 8 please.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Sinking of Trawler off Skerries (Dublin).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether it is the case, as reported, that he personally ordered an inquiry by the Naval Service into the recent sinking of a trawler off Skerries, County Dublin; and, if so, in pursuance of which statutory or other authority he was acting in so ordering.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: Immediately I became aware of this incident I decided, as Head of Government, that it was sufficiently serious to merit full investigation by the appropriate authorities, and I so directed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach not agree that the appropriate Minister to direct an inquiry into an event of this type is Deputy Wilson? What powers was the Taoiseach purporting to exercise in giving any directions in this matter at all?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I gave this direction in pursuance of the general power which resides in me as Head of the Government. The Deputy must realise that this incident took place on a Sunday afternoon and at the early stages it was not quite clear under whose auspices the matter correctly fell. It could have been a naval matter, it could have been a fisheries matter or, as the Deputy rightly pointed out, it could have been a matter for the Minister for Transport. The action I took on that day was to ask all the different bodies who could conceivably have an interest in the matter to look into it immediately. Subsequently it transpired that the matter is one more appropriately dealt with by the Minister for Transport under the legislation which he administers and that course of action is being followed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Now that the Taoiseach has taken an interest in this tragic if outrageous occurence, could he tell us whether he has any proposals to see that the skipper and owners of this vessel whose livelihoods depend on it will be properly compensated and put back in business?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I accept the validity of that suggestion and I assure the Deputy that the matter is being actively pursued by Bord Iascaigh Mhara who are in consultation with the skipper and an offer has actually been made to him with precisely the objectives the Deputy has mentioned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Will the Taoiseach see that adequate compensation is paid for this extraordinary and unusual cause of damage?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: I cannot give a specific undertaking of that nature because the Deputy will understand that the situation at present is that a preliminary investigation has been made by the Minister for Transport with a view to deciding whether to set up a formal inquiry. In advance of that inquiry and its findings it is difficult to decide at this stage what might or might not be done. I assure the Deputy, and I know the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry has this question in mind, that we are anxious to ensure that the skipper in question does not suffer any detrimental effect as a result of this incident.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Would the Taoiseach or the Minister concerned keep the House informed about this matter?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Charles J. Haughey
Speaker.P: We will certainly do that and, as I said, BIM have already made a very good offer to the skipper. I am not sure whether that offer will be accepted but there was an immediate response by BIM.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Live Register Numbers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the number on the live register at an appropriate date in January and June in each year since 1960.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern)
Speaker.P: I propose to circulate a tabular statement setting out the information requested by the Deputy.
Following is the statement:
Number of persons on the live register on the last Friday of January and June in each year since 1960.

MainHeading.P: Note: It should be borne in mind that changes made in the administration of the social welfare regulations and other changes in the coverage of the live register affect the comparability of these figures over such a long period of years.
The principal considerations which affect the comparability of the figures are:
(a) The figures for the period from 1966 to 1982 exclude persons on systematic short-time and persons aged 65 years and over whereas such persons are included in the figures for earlier years.
(b) The conditions under which persons are eligible for social insurance cover have been changed from time to time.
(c) Following the introduction of the Social Welfare (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1965, smallholders were excluded from the live register as from January 1966.

(d) The operation of employment period orders for the period from 1960 to 1966 and again in 1971 excluded certain persons from the receipt of unemployment assistance between March and November in each of these years.
(e) The conditions which applied to single women and widows who were applicants for unemployment assistance were relaxed from 1 October 1978.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Collins Mr. E. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the number on the live register at the latest available date; the national percentage of unemployment in the country based on the live register; and the number on the live register for each of the employment exchanges in the country at the same date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern) Minister for State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. B. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The number of persons on the live register on 26 March 1982, the latest date for which information is available, was 148,004. This represents 12.0 per cent of the estimated total labour force.
I propose to circulate a statement showing the number of persons on the live register at each local employment office on 26 March 1982.

MainHeading.P: Following is the statement:
Number of persons on the live register at each local employment office on 26 March 1982.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - National Parents Council.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether it is his intention to proceed with the setting up of a national parents council; if so, when he expects such a council to come into operation; and if he will give details of its financing etc.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue) Minister for Education (Professor O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: Submissions were invited by way of advertisement in the press on 18 February 1982 from interested parties as to the possible structure, responsibilities and method of election of a national parents council. When the submissions have been received and examined, the matter of the establishment of such a council, and other related matters, will be given due consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Has any consideration been given to the question of financing and, if so, what kind of funding is the Minister speaking about?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: As I indicated in my reply, other related matters will be given due consideration in the context of examining the submissions. It would be premature at this stage to try to anticipate the outcome of such examination.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Arising out of the Minister's reply, is he proposing to set up a council without terms of reference? Will the terms of reference be laid down by the Minister before the council is set up?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I have made no such proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): What terms of reference will operate?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: The first step is to receive submissions from all interested parties, to have those carefully examined and, when that procedure has been followed, I will, of course, formulate some proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: The Minister said he has not given consideration to the question of funding this council. Is it possible that the council might be set up and expectations raised which could not be subsequently honoured unless the Minister gives some idea as to the question of what kind of resources will be available?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Deputy Boland, your question has been answered by supplementaries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not be prepared to honour the undertaking which had previously been given, that the Department of Education should supply the funding so as to provide a secretariat for any such proposed council?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Related matters, such as the funding, secretariat or any other relevant arrangements would all be dealt with in the context of decisions emerging from examination of the various submissions. I share the Deputy's wish to see parents having an adequate role in the operation of our educational system. For that reason, I am interested in receiving the submissions which are coming in as a result of decisions he had taken but I think at this juncture it would be wrong of me to anticipate the outcome of that examination.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Glenasmole (Dublin) National School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will authorise speech and drama classes during school hours in Glenasmole national school, County Dublin, in accordance with the requests of parents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if his Department will provide school transport to Glenasmole national school, County Dublin to enable a speech and drama class to be conducted.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions Nos. 15 and 16 together.

Speech training and drama form an integral part of the programme in national schools. It is a fundamental constituent of the new curriculum and a detailed syllabus for all students is outlined in the programme.

If the parents concerned wish to organise additional classes in speech and drama, for which I understand a fee would be payable, it would be open to them to do so outside school hours. The use of the school building for such classes after school hours would be subject to the general conditions applicable including the permission of the board of management.
It would not be open to me under the terms of the school transport scheme to provide free transport to enable such an extra activity to take place.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that this school — I am sure it applies to other schools — is a small school in a rural area which is not served by a public bus service? Does that not militate against children having speech and drama classes? There are two ways to do it, either to permit the classes during normal school hours or to have the Minister provide them with a school bus. Is not the Minister, in effect, debarring children in all rural areas without bus services from having the benefit of this type of training, which is readily available to city children?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I do not accept that children are being debarred from this type of facility because, as I pointed out in my reply, speech training and drama are a constituent or integral part of the programme in national schools. Therefore, such training can be and is provided during normal school hours. The Deputy also asked whether there could be provision for an additional class specifically catering for speech and drama teaching outside normal hours as is being done in a number of schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that in this school 30 of the 55 children attending, have, through their parents, opted for speech and drama classes? The parents have available the services of a teacher and they have made provision for the payment of the teacher's salary. However, they are unable to proceed further with the scheme because the Department have refused permission to have these classes during school hours. If that is not permitted the whole project falls, because the children have not got transport to get home after normal school-leaving time. That is the problem in the case of this rural school. The Minister has said it is an authorised part of the curriculum but the practicality is that it cannot be done in a small rural school because there is no public transport. It must be either within the school hours or the Minister must provide the transport.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I recognise the point the Deputy is making but does he in turn not recognise that it could be extremely expensive and complex to organise a second system of school transport to cater for after-hours activities? It would be unreasonable to begin to make arrangements of that nature for one or two schools without organising it for all schools. It would not be practicable to organise two sequences of school transport in rural areas. As I indicated in my reply, in the context of the existing school transport system it is not open to me to make any such special arrangements for any one school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: What the Minister is saying is, in effect, a discrimination against children attending rural schools: they are being discriminated against, in effect, by being unable to get the benefit of this course which the Minister agrees is part of the curriculum. Whatever expense may be necessary to dispense with such discrimination ought to be undertaken.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I assure the Deputy that for 20 years I have been aware of many forms of discrimination being operated at various levels of education, depending on the context of rural or urban children and children from different social categories. The desirable objective is to have equality of opportunity for all pupils in comparable circumstances. I do not see how I can organise special arrangements for one school in this instance without considering the consequences for other schools. Of course the other side of the coin is that if I cannot arrange it for all schools I do not think it would be right to prevent such schools that are in a position to offer additional activities for their pupils from doing so. That would be just as undesirable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: If there are difficulties in providing a further bus service, the situation could be met if the Department, with the approval of the school board, allowed these classes to take place during school hours. That would not cost anything. All that is required is the Minister's permission. Would the Minister do that?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I suggest to the Deputy that we examine the situation more fully in that context. If necessary, we could then have a further question or a discussion on it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Corporal Punishment in Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he accepts the decision of his predecessor to abolish corporal punishment in our schools; and, if so, if he will make a statement as to the substitute arrangements, if any, he proposes to introduce.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: The current situation in relation to school discipline is as set our in Circulars 9/82 and M. 5/82 issued in January 1982.

MainHeading.P: As already stated by me, I propose at an early date to establish a working party representative of management and teaching interests as well as of parent views to advise on the maintenance of discipline in schools, with special reference to the problem of disruptive pupils.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: If the Minister accepts his predecessor's decision, what is his advice to teachers who find themselves in great difficulty because of the necessity to impose some semblance of discipline in classrooms? When does he expect to be able to issue final guidelines on this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: As I indicated, the position is that the prevailing code relating to school discipline was published in January last. The question of dealing with any problems of school discipline arising from the new arrangements is of interest and concern to school managements, and parents in some instance. There have been a number of discussions on the subject and, as I have indicated, as a result of those discussions I have arranged to put in motion the setting up of a representative committee. In the interim, essentially it is a matter for the management of each school to decide on the appropriate action to be taken.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: In a case where discipline of some description must be imposed, will the Minister accept whatever the management boards decide to do?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Provided it is within the general context of the rules for the operation of schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Owen Mrs. Owen
Speaker.P: Will the Minister confirm that at the moment the main alternative to corporal punishment is suspension? Will he further confirm that this is useless in a lot of schools where the children are only too willing to have a day or a week off school?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I am aware that suspension has been used as a disciplinary measure and I have discussed the merits and demerits of that with a number of people representative of management and with other interested parties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Do I understand the Minister to say that he intends establishing a working party comprising representatives of the teaching interests, management interests and parents?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Is that working party a replacement of the working party which it had been intended to set up in relation to which the management and teaching interests had been invited to nominate representatives.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I am not sure whether it is a replacement but, as my predecessor will know, no committee had been established prior to the change of Government and therefore I have inherited a set of questions associated with this action of my predecessor.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I appreciate——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I am sorry, Deputy. I have allowed six suplementaries already and we have 558 oral questions. I am calling Question No. 18.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I appreciate that. But I am not interested in whether or not the Minister has inherited a set of questions. What I want to establish is whether or not the teaching interests have now agreed to have parent representation on the working party.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I did not outline the detailed organisational arrangements by which this examination is taking place.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: On the contrary, did the Minister not say that the working party would comprise various interests, incluing parents?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: My reply was that a working party, representative of management and teaching interests as well as of parents' views, would advise on the maintenance of discipline in schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Does the phrase “as well as of parents' views” mean that there will be parent representation on the working party?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: It means that I am making arrangements to ensure that the views of all interested parties are fully taken into account.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Does it mean that the teaching unions have removed their veto on having parents represented on the working party?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: This is not an interrogation. Your colleague, Deputy Noonan, is waiting to ask a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): Do the Minister's Department allow the detention of national school children after school hours on the school premises as a punishment and do the Department cover such children by insurance?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I am not familiar with the details of insurance arrangements for schools. I will inquire into the matter. I assume that insurance does apply and I am aware that detention is used as a form of punishment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): Will the Minister check the insurance situation?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I will indeed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: Is the Minister not prepared to answer my last question?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I am sorry. It had been overtaken by a subsequent supplementary. I have had a number of constructive discussions with the teaching organisations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: But have the teaching organisations agreed to have parent representation on the working party?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Question No. 18 has been called.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Boland Mr. Boland
Speaker.P: I presume that means the reply is in the negative.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: It means the Minister is retaining flexibility.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Registration of Architects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he proposes to introduce legislation to provide for the registration of architects; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he proposes to introduce legislation to provide for the registration of architects in Ireland having regard to the present situation within the European Economic Community; and the proposals for self certification by architects and others in relation to implementation of the draft building regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 21 and 22 together.

I have no proposals under consideration at present for the introduction of legislation to provide for the registration of architects. I understand that prior to October 1979 negotiations were taking place between the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Energy and the various bodies concerned but that agreement could not be reached in the matter. As the Deputy is aware, the draft EEC directive in the field of architecture has been under discussion since 1967 and is still under consideration.

In relation to the draft building regulations I understand from the Minister for the Environment that the proposed system of control to administer the building regulations is based on a system of certification and that these proposals have not yet been finalised.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: This question was, in fact, put down to the Minister for the Environment but has been transferred to the Minister's Department. Since Government Departments—irrespective of whatever politician has the misfortune to be responsible for them—seem to be reluctant to take up this matter, and since it has now been foisted upon the Minister for Education, and since a real problem arises regarding building regulations, could I ask the Minister if he will undertake to give a clear indication as to when the question of certification/registration will be effectively dealt with?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I will certainly give an undertaking to the Deputy to have the matter examined urgently. I read through the history of it and one gets the impression that there is no great sense of speed or urgency on the part of a number of the other members of the community. So I am not in a position to say how quickly they can be brought to subscribe to some community decision in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Can I take it that the Minister and his Department now have responsibility for registration?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Yes.
Question No. 23 postponed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - New Regional Technical Colleges.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will ensure that the new regional technical colleges to be established will confer degrees on their graduates.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: The appropriate qualifications in respect of level of courses in regional technical colleges are awarded by the National Council for Educational Awards. Regional technical colleges to be established in the future will be administered on the same basis and provide similar courses, with due regard to variations related to regional needs, as existing colleges.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: The purport of the question is that the standard of the award for the regional technical colleges should be those of degrees to put them on a par with the universities. Would the Minister favour that view and ensure that that will be done rather than awarding a lesser qualification?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: There is no restriction as to the level of qualification which a regional technical college may be able to provide for its students. But the question of whether a degree should be awarded is a matter between the regional technical college concerned and the NCEA who have discussions with the college and agree on the various levels of curriculum and so forth.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: It is agreed that it would be appropriate that, where a regional technical college would conduct a full-time three-or four-year course the status of a degree would be awarded to graduates rather than something less such as a diploma or something of that sort?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I do not want to give a non-qualified or blanket agreement to arrangements of that kind because the other consideration which has to be taken into account is whether or not it would be appropriate to extend in any one instance the number of institutions offering a degree level course in a specific subject. For example, in a relatively specialised area in which there might be a comparatively small number of students it would be wasteful of very expensive educational resources to allow a large number of institutions to offer these courses. Decisions as to the number and nature of degree level courses offered by bodies such as regional technical colleges should be decided on in the context not only of their own circumstances but of their relationship to third level institutions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I have allowed many supplementaries on this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: ——that, if it becomes the pattern that regional technical colleges award a qualification of a lesser status than degree, that would downgrade their status and make them second class third level institutions not comparable with other third level institutions? Would the Minister desire to see such a situation?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I can only answer by referring to the experience of the existing regional technical colleges. They were first put forward in 1967 and since they opened their doors over a decade ago they have proved their value and have been accepted as institutions of third level education which have no difficulty in attracting students. They have had no difficulty in having their worth and value recognised both in the educational community and the community at large.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers - Higher Education Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will remove the anomaly whereby one year art and design students are ineligible for a higher education grant in view of the fact that the course is part of a three year third level educational programme.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Foundation year/pre-diploma year courses in art are accepted for the purpose of the tenure of grants under the higher education grants scheme where they are specifically recognised by the National Council for Educational Awards for the purpose of its awards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will dispense with the rule whereby it is essential to apply for the higher education grant in the year of sitting for the leaving certificate examination in order to facilitate persons who wish to, or need to, seek employment for some years before entering third level education.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: The position under the existing provisions of the higher education grants scheme is that in the case of a student who qualifies academically for a grant in the leaving certificate examination of a particular year and who takes up employment for up to two years before entering on a third level course of education, my Department would offer no objection to the relevant local authority accepting an application for grant from such student and treating it as if it had been received on or before the closing date in the year the student sat for the leaving certificate examination. Accordingly, the concession sought in the Deputy's question is already provided for in the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: It is only granted in part. Would the Minister not agree that the concession period referred to of two years is entirely arbitrary and that it would be appropriate to extend that period to provide for the case of people who have a qualification to enter university but require to work for a period longer than two years in order to obtain sufficient financial means to enable them to do so?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: To anticipate a later question, I am conscious that certain aspects of the operation of the grant scheme should be looked at. In that context, it will be examined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): In the case of a student who takes up employment for two years is eligibility for a grant purposes decided on the means of the working student or the parents in the leaving certificate year?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: It is normally decided on the circumstances that obtained in the year in which he sat the examination. The situation is that, if he completed employment and then applied for a grant, the assumption is that he would be giving up employment so that he would not have an income of his own on which to be assessed. If the Deputy would table a question——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): Is the Minister aware that the difficulty and stupidity of the present grant scheme is that regardless of the age of the student, the assessment is always made by reference to the means of the parents in the year of certification? In the cases where a student is married and has a child he is still assessed on the means of the parents. Would the Minister look at the situation with a view to removing this ridiculous anomaly?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I should prefer if the Deputy did not use colourful descriptions. In fairness to any schemes in operation, including this, one must begin by having a set of rules. I recall that when the scheme was introduced it only operated for students who took up the grant in the year in which they sat the examination. It was to improve the scheme that the two year deferral was introduced. Various other improvements have been built into the scheme since it was introduced. It is unfortunate to refer to an improvement as stupid. I recognise that there is always scope for further improvement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): I suppose it is under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will remove the anomaly whereby in order to become eligible for a higher education grant, it is necessary to have achieved four honours in the leaving certificate examination in the case of applicants for courses which require less than four honours for entry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will arrange do dispense with the rule requiring four honours to be achieved in one sitting of the leaving certificate examination for eligibility for a higher education grant, having regard to the fact that this rule militates against mature and/or married prospective students.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 28 and 29 together.

MainHeading.P: The rule at present is that in order to qualify for a grant a candidate must have obtained successes as follows in the leaving certificate examination of the year in question: Either (1) Grade C or a higher grade in higher or common level papers in four or more subjects; or (2) Grade C or a higher grade in higher or common level papers in Irish and in two other subjects or in mathematics and in two other subjects; or (3) in the case of a candidate who will pursue an approved course in science (including agricultural science) or engineering, Grade C or a higher grade in higher or common level papers in two of the following subjects: mathematics, applied mathematics, physics, chemistry, physics and chemistry, agricultural science, technical drawing, agricultural economics.
Since coming into office I have noted for review a number of areas within the higher education grants scheme. I am not in a position, however, to anticipate what the results of that review may be.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that an effect of the regulations which he read out will be that there could be cases where a person would have achieved sufficient qualifications for a course and yet that would be insufficient to enable him to qualify for the grant? Is it not logical and desirable that, if a student gets sufficient marks in his examination to qualify him for a grant, that should be adequate for grant qualification purposes?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: The distinction which the Deputy refers to between qualification for entry and qualification for grant has existed since the scheme was introduced in 1968.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: That does not make it right.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I am replying. To make the change suggested would increase the number of students qualifying for grants. It would not necessarily be the most appropriate use of any additional financial resources which might become available. I am reviewing the operation of the scheme but I do not wish to anticipate the results of that review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Noonan (Limerick-East) Mr. M. Noonan (Limerick-East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick-East): Is the review taking place at present and when does the Minister expect a report?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: I do not want to put a date on it. I requested that it be as a matter of urgency. I expect to have some preliminary results within the next few months.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Question No. 30, Deputy Taylor.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will remove the anomaly whereby third level students in the Mater Dei Institute, Dublin, are ineligible for higher education grants.

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: Courses which in content and character are essentially courses in religious studies have not heretofore been accepted for the purpose of the tenure of grants under the higher education grants scheme. I do not propose to make any change in that position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that it is entirely illogical that third level students of the Mater Dei Institute in Dublin, doing a four-year course which is validated by Saint Patrick's College, Maynooth, whose qualification is accepted by his own Department for teaching purposes at second level, should be debarred in this way?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: It has always been the position that any courses which in any sense have an element of religious studies in them are not recognised for the purposes of secular education grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that, while it has always been the position until now, logic requires that now is the time to change it?

Speaker.hpid: Professor O'Donoghue Professor O'Donoghue
Speaker.P: It is not just a simple matter of logic which the Deputy has in mind.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The remaining questions will appear on tomorrow's Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: I had a question down to the Taoiseach regarding instructions from his Department to the College of Art in Dublin to seek the return of the Chester Beatty paintings from the Cork Gallery and you, Sir, ruled it out of order as being argumentative, even though it is a matter within the competence of the Taoiseach's Department. May I have the reasons for your ruling?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I have studied the question and I have also sought the advice of my advisers. It was adjudged argumentative.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: If it is a matter in which the Taoiseach has responsibility, surely the question should be allowed and he should answer it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Not a question that is argumentative.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: It was not argumentative. All I sought to do was to ask——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Sorry, Deputy, you are not allowed to question——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: ——the Taoiseach to instruct——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: It is out of order to question the ruling of the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: It should be allowed.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Deputy, it is not within your rights to question a decision of the Chair when a question is disallowed. You are welcome to discuss it with me at my office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: That does not get the question down on the Order Paper for answer by the Taoiseach, and the matter is his responsibility.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: If you will discuss it with me, we will review it in the light——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: I ask you to allow it on the Order Paper for next week.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: If it is proved not argumentative, I will indeed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: That seems an awful waste of time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: On a point of order regarding the questions on the Order Paper today, at the last sitting of the Dáil prior to the Easter recess on 1 April I asked for a written answer to Question No. 153 on that occasion. In the written answer the Minister included Questions Nos. 154 and 155 of that day. I had not requested a written answer to either of those questions. You have now disallowed my question to the Minister for Justice on the basis that it was answered previously.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I will look into the matter further.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hussey Mrs. Hussey
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I wish to raise on the Adjournment of the House the abrupt closure of the National Film Studios of Ireland on 3 April and the subsequent threat to employment, tourism and the Irish film industry.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I would like the Minister for Industry and Energy to make a statement on the problems at Quigley Magnesite Ltd., Dungarvan, County Waterford, which is in trouble and may close with the loss of 150 jobs.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: That is a matter for a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: There is great urgency about it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: You can put down a question on that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: On the question of your ruling on the grounds that a question was argumentative, I have a question down to the Taoiseach about a deal between himself and Deputy Blaney which is covering the front pages of all the Northern papers.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: There is a rule in the House that you cannot question at this time a decision of the Chair. I did not make the rule.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Why has the Chair disallowed the question on the grounds that it was argumentative when there was nothing argumentative about it?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: That is your opinion. I am sorry, you cannot raise that even at this time.

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Questions. - Restoration of Dublin Telephone Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if, in view of the recent collapse in Dublin city of two old buildings with consequent danger to the public, and the total failure of his Department to respond to repeated requests from Dublin Corporation and public representatives to have the 24-hour telephone service to the dangerous buildings section of the corporation repaired, he will indicate in the interests of public safety when service will be restored.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Leyden) Terry Leyden
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Leyden);
Speaker.P: I share the Deputy's concern that the dangerous buildings service provided by Dublin Corporation should not be impeded for want of telephone facilities. The telephone number of the service is 746235, which is answered in Belvedere Court during normal office hours. This telephone is working normally. However, there is a fault on a tie-line to an after-office-hours location. Callers to 746235 after office hours are advised to ring an alternative number 420174. Both 746235 and 420174 are afforded the highest priority. And investigation is being carried out into the fault on the tie-line.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Would the Minister of State agree that buildings do not have the kind of discipline that you or I have and, therefore, do not arrange to fall down during office hours? Arising from that unfortunate lack of discipline on their part there is a necessity for a 24-hour emergency service and a caller who rings the first telephone number which the Minister cited to the House will get an automatic answering service. The reaction of many people in panic on hearing such a service is to abandon listening to it any further. The problem is one of the maintenance section of the Department of Posts and Telegraphs fixing this tie-line.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: I am in a profession similar to that of Deputy Quinn, and so I am well aware of the difficulties with buildings and the possible danger involved in the collapse of a building. I assure the Deputy that I have given specific instructions that this tie-line will be repaired forthwith and I hope that that will be cleared within the next few days. The facilities have been provided with an answering call on this line which will go to a phone which is numbered. Both those phones are maintained by my Department on a 24-hours basis. I thank the Deputy for bringing this to our attention and I assure him that the matter will be attended to as a top priority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: In thanking the Minister of State for his reply I ask him, on behalf of Dublin Corporation, if his Department will now pay for the cost of the advertisement which had to be placed in the newspapers during the breakdown of this service and also for the hiring of the automatic answering service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: I would not be able to give that type of assurance to the Deputy. We provided an alternative service to Dublin Corporation.

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Questions. - Restoration of Parcel Post.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he is aware of the severe hardships being experienced by industrial and commercial firms, particularly small companies and very particularly the general public, as a result of a decision to suspend the acceptance and collection of parcel post within the Republic; if he is aware of the damage this decision is causing all companies engaged in exports and the subsequent effect all this is having on employment and the economy, and in view of the seriousness of the situation, if he will restore the parcel post immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Wilson)
Speaker.P: I am aware that the suspension of the parcel post service is causing inconvenience to business and to the public generally. However, I regret that it was necessary to suspend the service because the postmen drivers did not pass the picket placed by the National Busmen's Union at Connolly Station, which is the main distribution centre for the conveyance of parcel mail. The service remains suspended as the drivers continue not to pass the picket. Because of the very considerable bulk of daily parcel postings, it is unfortunately not practicable to make alternative arrangements which would enable the service to be fully restored. The question of a limited restoration of the service, which would not involve the normal use of Connolly Station, is under active consideration at present by my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: The Minister must be misinformed. In the short time that I was in the Department of Posts and Telegraphs I learned that about 4,500 bags of mail——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: A question, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Yes, I am asking it. About 4,500 bags of mail are collected there and processed each day. In an agreement with van drivers they cleared off in a matter of hours three days' accumulation of mail which amounted to something between 12,000 and 13,000 bags per day despite the fact that the general manager of the ITGWU said today that it is 10,000 bags. Bear in mind that there is a chain-link conveyor system between Sheriff Street and Connolly Station capable of moving 12,000 bags per day as against a need of 4,500 bags per day. Is the Minister telling the House that there is no way in which this dispute can be resolved? People in Donegal must cross the Border to post goods to other parts of the Republic.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The chain conveyor link is in use for letter mail. That service is being provided and is up-to-date. The Deputy should also be aware that we are still delivering a substantial quantity of parcels from both the UK and the United States. Post office workers are not passing this picket and for that reason the parcel post is suspended for the moment. The huge bulk of the parcel post is the problem but we are hoping to establish a limited restoration of service. At the same time we are urging that the workers should pass the pickets. Leaders of the Post Office Workers' Union are asking their members to pass the pickets and members of other unions are doing so. Deputy Harte has made a very good point about the seriousness of this problem for small industries and so on. If the workers passed the pickets full service could be restored in a very short time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I am not satisfied. The Minister represents a Border constituency and he must appreciate that small companies——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Could the Deputy ask a short supplementary?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I am asking whether the Minister appreciates that small companies are now being discriminated against. Firms that are importing——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: This is more a statement than a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister if he is aware that imports are being delivered and paid for by the taxpayers while small companies which manufacture goods for export cannot do so because of the stubborn attitude of the Minister in not meeting the people in Sheriff Street and working out some arrangement with them. There is a conveyor belt system there which is quite capable of coping with the number of parcels which are——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The Deputy has asked a supplementary question and should now allow it to be answered. He may not make a statement and we must move on to another Private Notice Question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I assure the Deputy that I am aware there is a serious problem in this field and that small industries are being hit hardest. There is pressure from my Department and from the leaders of the unions to pass the picket at Connolly Station but this has not succeeded in persuading workers from the POWU to do so, despite the fact that workers from other unions are passing the picket. A considerable bulk of parcels from the UK and the United States are being delivered and we are now trying to put together a scheme whereby we can get a limited parcel post service operating, without using Connolly Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: This is a very serious matter.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I know that, but we cannot have a debate on it. I have allowed a number of supplementaries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I resent the Chair trying to curtail the debate.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I will not allow any more supplementary questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister to become involved personally in this dispute.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: You have already asked that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: Will you let me give my reasons, please?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: You are entitled to ask a supplementary and that is all.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister personally to take an interest in what is happening.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: You have repeated your supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: People are being forced to go to Northern Ireland to post their goods to other parts of the Republic.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: You have said that already.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: We are losing the revenue and small industries are being put to great inconvenience. The Minister has done sweet Fanny Adams about it. He is not interested in his work and should admit it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I repeat very firmly that I have taken and am taking a personal interest in this problem and I do not accept this bluster from Deputy Harte.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I will set up an office in my own constituency.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Harte Mr. Harte
Speaker.P: It will be the first thing the Minister has ever done for it.

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Questions. - Telephone Repair Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he has authorised changes in the 24-hour telephone repair service and, if so, when did he do so, the different categories and the persons involved in the new changes he has made, and if medical doctors are now being regarded in lower priority for these repair services than heretofore.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: As announced by the previous Government, the financial allocation for overtime in the Post Office Estimate in the current year has been greatly reduced — from an expenditure of over £34 million last year at the pay rates in force throughout 1981 to £23.7 million in the current year at the increased rates of pay applicable throughout 1982. To keep within the reduced provision, the volume of overtime worked throughout the Department has been scaled down drastically. Despite this other measures have to be taken to keep within the approved allocation.

MainHeading.P: One of these measures is to curtail, on an experimental basis, with effect from 19 April the number of subscribers in the Dublin area whose telephones are repaired after normal working hours. The cost of calling out staff to attend to an individual fault can be as much as £50 and in quite a number of cases where staff are called out it is not possible to repair the fault until more staff become available during normal working hours. The intention is that the new arrangements should be operated in a flexible way and with discretion to go outside the limits of the revised arrangements if individual circumstances warrant it. The effects of the restrictions will be monitored on a continuing basis and changes made if these are considered essential.
All categories whose telephones were formerly repaired outside normal working hours will, of course, continue to get priority attention during normal hours.
